page.title:
Objectives
Objectives
page.normal_text:
This module presents the fundamentals of intellectual property, including the following topics:
This module presents the fundamentals of
intellectual property, including the following topics:

(1) Definition of Intellectual Property (IP)
(1) Definition of Intellectual Property (IP)

(2) Importance & far-reaching effects of IP
(2) Importance & far-reaching effects of IP

(3) Rights reserved to the rightful IP owner
(3) Rights reserved to the rightful IP owner

(4) Increasing importance of University’s role in IP
(4) Increasing importance of University’s role in IP

page.title:
What is Intellectual Property
What is Intellectual Property
page.normal_text:
4 types of intellectual property:
4 types of intellectual property:

(1) Copyright
(1) Copyright

(2) Trademark
(2) Trademark

(3) Trade Secrets
(3) Trade Secrets

(4) Patent

page.title:
Intellectual Property Process
Intellectual Property Process

Copyright
Copyright
page.normal_text:
Definition: A form of protection provided to the authors of
Definition: A form of protection provided to the authors of
page.enlisting:
“original works of authorship”
“original works of authorship”
page.normal_text:
Protects:
Protects:

Literary, dramatic, musical, artistic, and certain other intellectual works
Literary, dramatic, musical, artistic, and certain
other intellectual works

Duration:
Duration:

In general, author’s life + 70 years
In general, author’s life + 70 years

For more information on copyright, visit the U.S. Copyright Office website at http://www.copyright.gov
For more information on copyright,
visit the U.S. Copyright Office website at
http://www.copyright.gov

page.title:
Trademark
Trademark
page.normal_text:
Definition: Any word, name, symbol, or device, or any
Definition: Any word, name, symbol, or device, or any

combination, used, or intended to be used, in commerce to identify and distinguish the goods or services
combination, used, or intended to be used, in
commerce to identify and distinguish the
goods or services

Protects:
Protects:

All of the above & logo, banner, sound, smell, etc.
All of the above & logo, banner, sound, smell, etc.

Duration:
Duration:

10-year terms with 10-year renewal terms
10-year terms with 10-year renewal terms

page.title:
Trade Secrets
Trade Secrets
page.normal_text:
Definition: Any information that provides economic value
Definition: Any information that provides economic value

that is not in the public domain and that has been reasonably kept secret
that is not in the public domain and that has
been reasonably kept secret

Protects:
Protects:

Formulas, patterns, compilations, programs, devices, methods, techniques or processes
Formulas, patterns, compilations, programs,
devices, methods, techniques or processes

Duration:
Duration:

As long as they remain secret
As long as they remain secret

page.title:
Patent
Patent
page.normal_text:
Definition: A grant of property rights by the U.S.
Definition: A grant of property rights by the U.S.

Government through the USPTO
Government through the USPTO

Patentability: “Whoever invents or discovers any new
Patentability: “Whoever invents or discovers any new

and useful process, machine, manufacture, or composition of matter, or any new and useful improvement thereof, may obtain a patent” (35 U.S.C. 101)
and useful process, machine, manufacture,
or composition of matter, or any new and
useful improvement thereof, may obtain a
patent” (35 U.S.C. 101)

Duration:
Duration:

page.title:
What is a Patent
What is a Patent
page.normal_text:
Purpose:
Purpose:

To promote the progress of science and useful arts… (U.S. Constitution Article I, §8, Clause 8)
To promote the progress of science and useful
arts… (U.S. Constitution Article I, §8, Clause 8)

System:
System:

A quid pro quo; Disclosure of the invention to the government in specific terms, in exchange for exclusive rights to the inventor
A quid pro quo;
Disclosure of the invention to the government
in specific terms, in exchange for exclusive
rights to the inventor

Filing for a Patent – Why bother?

Rights included in a Patent
Rights included in a Patent

page.title:
Who Enforces Patent Infringements
Who Enforces Patent Infringements
page.normal_text:
Infringement: Violation of any of the patent rights
Infringement: Violation of any of the patent rights

Enforcement: Up to patent owner, not USPTO.
Enforcement: Up to patent owner, not USPTO.

The USPTO-granted rights valid only in U.S.
The USPTO-granted rights valid only in U.S.

PCT : Enables a U.S. applicant to file an international utility patent application in a standardized format at USPTO. A filing system; and it does not grant a patent
PCT : Enables a U.S. applicant to file an international utility
patent application in a standardized format at USPTO.
A filing system; and it does not grant a patent

page.title:
Patentable & Non-patentable subject matters
Patentable & Non-patentable
subject matters
page.normal_text:
Patentable subject matters: “… any new and useful process, machine, manufacture, or composition of matter, or any new and useful improvement thereof… Software and business methods also patentable
Patentable subject matters:
“… any new and useful process, machine,
manufacture, or composition of matter, or any
new and useful improvement thereof…
Software and business methods also patentable

• Filed for filing date priority

page.title:
Filing a Patent Application in U.S. and in other countries
Filing a Patent Application in
U.S. and in other countries
page.normal_text:
U.S.: The real person or persons who first made the invention (i.e. the first to invent), or his/her assignee, is entitled to a patent
U.S.:
The real person or persons who first made the invention
(i.e. the first to invent), or his/her assignee, is entitled to a
patent

Other countries around the world: The first to file a complete application is entitled to a patent, provided the invention was not copied from another
Other countries around the world:
The first to file a complete application is entitled to a patent,
provided the invention was not copied from another
